Good aim trainer BUT has two big dealbreakers plus a problem with the training program:

First, it requires an online account separate from Steam. This nearly always gets a thumbs-down from me.
Second, the Discord channel, which seems to be the main way of getting support for the game, requires verifying a phone number, which is a privacy violation. Another thumbs-down from me.

As for the trainer itself: The training exercises do not compensate for field-of-view being different from the defaults. I quickly reached a stage where many of the training dummies were outside my FOV. I normally play games with a 90 degree FOV, but the defaults for KovaaK's are higher.
EDIT: This tool was narrowly spared from being refunded once I realized I can scale my DPI proportionally to my FOV in order to use the FOV KovaaK's seems to "require."

how to make delicious Butter Chicken.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients for 4 servings,
2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed
salt, to taste
pepper, to taste
2 teaspoons chili powder, divided
¬Ω teaspoon turmeric
6 tablespoons butter, divided
1 ¬Ω cups yellow onion (225 g), diced
3 teaspoons garam masala
1 teaspoon cumin
1 teaspoon cayenne pepper
1 tablespoon ginger, grated
3 cloves garlic, minced
1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick
14 oz tomato sauce (395 g)
1 cup water (240 mL)
1 cup heavy cream (240 mL)
rice, for serving
fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish.

Preparation
In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let
sit for 15 minutes to marinate.
Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot.
Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder,
the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant.
Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer.
Add the water and cream and return to a simmer.
Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes.
Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro.
Enjoy!

Review Overview:
I will be splitting this review into multiple sections. Look below to see a table of contents listing each and every segment. This review will be over-viewing some main general topics. This review will go more in depth about whats available in the game for your average day to day player, and what makes the game generally enjoyable and/or useful.

Table of Contents
Section 1: What is Kovaaks?

Section 1: What is Kovaaks?
Kovaaks is a aim trainer developed by The Meta Game INC. It was designed as a way for players to get inherently better at base mechanics like aim and all the facets that follows with, and soon exploded into a competitive score-reacher for many. Kovaaks gained much more popularity during the successes of early Valorant, encouraging many to practice and sharpen their aim and their skills. Kovaaks, Aimbeast, and Aimlabs are some of the most popular aim trainers known to date and all provide differing resources and experiences to improve your aim. 

Section 2: Positives of Kovaaks
Kovaaks very flexible, inbuilt nature allows players to test the limits of their aim in ways many would not find possible in other games or scenarios. There are well over 20,000 scenarios on Kovaaks, each of them providing different approaches to aiming and varying difficulties. Kovaaks is also very customizable, allowing for freedom of cross-hair changes, color of enemies, color of enemies when specifically aiming on them, and even smaller things like simulated input lag and others. Kovaaks is also very optimized so you should experience little to no lag or fps issues. Kovaaks supports many games such as Valorant, Apex Legends, Overwatch, and Quake, each group having many instances and scenarios for them to practice on to improve in their respective games. Another positive of Kovaaks is the community. Voltaic, known as one of the biggest aiming communities, is found mainly in Kovaaks and their extensive research and databases go far into the idea of aim theory, allowing you to pursue your aim growth journey at full speed. Many are very supportive; willing to give advice at a winks notice, and plenty of guides and other useful information have been shared by Voltaic. If you'd like to join their discord, heres the link: https://discord.gg/voltaic

Section 3: Negatives of Kovaaks
Kovaaks, despite its greatness, has competition that are free. Because of Kovaaks paywall, that will always be a barrier for some looking to improve their aim. Another negative of Kovaaks is that it can be hard to begin aim training without a general grasp of how Kovaaks works. Many start Kovaaks with no real general direction and start to experiment, however many will also get lost and focus on the wrong things for the game they're intending to play, or just simply don't know where to start or what scenarios to play. This requires the user to be more receptive to knowledge and look for youtube guides and other things to even start their journey, which can be a hurdle for some. While Kovaaks has the highest general diversity for playable scenarios, other free aim trainers are coming with niche features that may give some the temptation to look into more affordable options. Aimlabs, for example, has a sensitivity finder, along with many playlists made by official valorant, csgo, and other big-title pros. 

Section 4: Conclusion
In conclusion, Kovaaks is an amazing way to improve aim, given dedication and effort is put in. I highly recommend playing Kovaaks if you are looking to improve at all aspects of your aim, and are willing to see results. As a reviewer, I saw massive improvements on multiple aspects of my game, and I found myself easily achieving never-seen before aim goals both in and out of game for myself. I came in an aim rookie and I came out with a sense of satisfaction, confidence, and accuracy. And that's not the end! to this day I still improve and sharpen my aim as much as possible with kovaaks. Highly recommend!

I beg you to please don't be like me and buy into the hype, this is not an ascendant aim trainer that pushes past the competition and limitations of it's contemporaries but one that sits squarely in the middle of the bunch. That there is a price tag attached to it is bewildering but it appears to come from a place of passion and the price does explain it's positive reception (sunk cost fallacy). It is my opinion that the unique features Kovaaks offers over software like Aim Labs or 3D Aim Trainer are better learned through playing whatever game you want to improve at.

I coast a consistently locked 144fps in Valorant, Overwatch 2, or any aim trainer I throw at my admittedly weak 1050ti, however Kovaaks at min settings brings my pc to it's knees, leaving me with a measly 50-60fps. Considering what this software is doing, the relative performance is unacceptable.

I expected the performance impact a compromise of the games strong polish in it's menus and assets but I can't say they impressed on any real level. A serious lack of weapon model customisation to accommodate a variety of games and somehow passing under the already low bar of unimpressive target models. Confusingly short menu windows designed around a save button that closes you out of the option menu and requires re-entry, is a head-scratcher to be sure. Ultrawide support that lacks scalability for non-stretched resolutions apart from native. UI/UX omissions expected in a free title but very odd indeed to see in a paid excursion.

In terms of user experience in navigating the program I would seat this just under Aim Labs in how it guides players to relevant playlists -which was also not spectacular for any beginner unsure of where to start. To offer some advice I recommend looking at 3D Aim Trainer and it's 'Become a Pro' training section that offers a selection of exercises targeting different categories of aim with ascending levels of difficulty in it's exercises and then providing a four 'tests' which summarises that users skill of that category of aim. I'm under no delusion that 3D Aim Trainer is perfect, these exercises are limited and not perfectly tuned for all games which is what turned me towards Kovaaks in the first place. However this is what I feel is missing from Kovaaks and Aim Labs, a comprehensive and accessible, clearly defined and digestible default segment of the software dedicated to onboarding new  players to receive a baseline level of raw aim that can later be expanded upon using playlists. Similar to how an irl gym functions, yes gym go-ers can do all the research to find a basic routine, weight amounts and number of repitions of exercises to that they will do but some will hire a personal trainer at the gym to add direction to their training and later build off that basic advice and direction once they've been properly acclimated to the environment and routine. 'Become a Pro' is a personal trainer and a guiding light to the uninitiated and that is what Kovaaks sorely lacks.

As it stands now I will continue to vouch for the aforementioned trainers. I hope to see Kovaaks expanded upon and polished up to truly be the crowning aim trainer.

Developed by The Meta, KovaaK's is the most famous paid Aim Trainer currently on the market as of the date of this review, widely compared favorably to AimLabs to the extent of being considered an excellent competitor.

The official website of this aim trainer is www.kovaak.com where players can also find content and programs/applications.

KovaaK's shares the same fame as AimLabs to the extent of being known far and wide even if the fact that it's paid means having a smaller playerbase compared to AimLabs, which is free. 

However, one of the most notable aspects of KovaaK's is the higher quality scenarios that can be found within it and significantly lower requirements compared to AimLabs, with it, there's something for everyone thanks to the possibility of being able to create your own scenarios and playlists, not to mention being also able to share your custom scenarios and playlists publicly as well, not unlike AimLabs.

Because of this, famous aim training services/routines to the likes of Voltaic (a free, publicly available aim training service operating mainly on Discord, initially made for AimLabs, featuring in-depth articles about the different aspects of aiming as well as ranked training routines to gauge your progress) also happen to feature a KovaaK's counterpart that are also publicly available for anyone to join them.

As expected, scenarios can range from easy to hard, cattering to different skill levels and also to improve different mechanical skills in regards to aim overall, even beginners with either mouse and keyboard or gyroscope gamepad players can also hone and sharpen their aiming skills in KovaaK's with the different options it offers.

Needless to say, both AimLabs and KovaaK's are the most famous aim trainers in the market as of the date of this review.

KovaaK's fame is to the point where content creators also made experiemnts with the aforementioned KovaaK's Aim Trainer when it comes to basically challenging themselves to use it for a month or so to see if it helped them in improving their aim, some of those videos reaching millions of views while also explicitly mentioning KovaaK's Aim Trainer as the aim trainer used during the video.

Highly recommended for either players looking to warm up before playing their favourite FPS game or as a mean to generally improve their aim, wether focusing mainly on perceived weaknesses in their aim with mouse or gyroscope gamepads, or for a more structured and organized experience as offered by services to the likes of Voltaic.

ITS ALL BEHIND A MONTHLY SUBSCRIPTION SERVICE.....THEY ARE NOW SOFTWARE AS A SERVICE that charges an initial fee like they are pay to own, and none of the other problems have been addressed, ones they have said they would fix for years. I payed for this product, it is a very unfinished product, there are bugs and oversight within all aspects of this product. Many times  you're playing a sandbox round,  It signals a round has started you are sure you'll be hitting your high score, then at some point you realize the round has gone on twice too long, you realize its a dud round your score hasn't been saved and the round will never end and you could have played ad infinitum. This is a common glitch, it happens at random, in default mode there is no round timer so you don't know its happening, and it leaves you constantly unsure wether your in a dud round or not. Which is not a good mind space, and a constant distraction while trying to improve and be scored. 

The tracking of your scores and improvements is poor and at most you can only see 4 data point in a graph of your  average (e.g 4 months of 1 month averages, 4 week of weekly average) in a graph. This means you cannot see long term trends(nothing longer then 4 months) . 

At the end of each round it ranks your high score against everyone elses, but this only updates if you beat your all time high score. If you don't top your old highscore youre not updated on how this current score ranks against other players. 

Finally, there is something they call a trainer it was a complete failure as a product and a large part of their marketing, it has a helper bot character that 'tailors' the training based on your performance. This is the largest failure of this program. It simply categorizes your missed shots into 4 directional quadrants, and if you miss too many shots in a single direction it recognizes this: two problems arise. BUT first every round will lack symmetry and this does not reveal a pattern unless it is considered over multiple rounds. 
first:  each level has requirements i.e 'hit percentage' 'number of hits in a row' , 'total hits' mainly. However there is a unspoken requirement that is never discussed. The necessity for symmetry  in your misses. You can greatly over achieve and beat the level requirements but if there is asymmetry in your missed shots you cannot pass. 
second: now it tailors the level so there are more shots in the quadrant you missed. However guess what happens when you have more shots in a certain quadrant, you guessed it. The number of missed shots goes up in that quadrant even if missed shots as a percentage of shots in that quadrant goes down. Call me crazy but they didn't foresee this and didn't program their program to calculate this number  in percentages, but instead in totals. So it creates an infinite feedback loop, where the bot continues to say you missed more in the same quadrant and add more shots to that quadrant. 
Further increasing shots to that quadrant, until you learn to completely ignore the bots feedback and not accept its 'changes'

They were unable to produce what they had hoped for so they kept it their hiding its function so they can justify charging you as a marketing ploy. 

The thing that offended me about all of this was that I believed it was a small developer working to fix these problems, rather slowly and I soldiered on. But  to see they had completely ignored this stuff and put this needed update behind a paywall has offended me greatly.

KovaaK's and AimLab are same but different. They accomplish the same thing but the means of assembly and presentation is where they differ the most. They do update the game for the games they collaborate with like Valorant and Siege, but KovaaK's has the arsenal of community. The community contributes greatly to the reason why KovaaK's is still around. There is soooooo much you can choose and select for yourself, on top of playlists that others share/recommend.

They are both good, and if you have money to burn, why not get this if you are serious about getting good at aiming and taking the time to do so. The range is far higher in selection if you are willing to search for the ones you want and get used to a somewhat clunky UI. If you don't want to spend money on an aim trainer or you just want to get training as fast as possible without the UI hurdles of KovaaKs, get AimLab. Either or, they both work for what they were designed to do: train aim.

tldr: Great aim trainer, god awful optimization

Probably the best aim trainer on the market (although probably mainly due to the community, see: Voltaic.gg). While they have that going for them, it's very poorly optimized for a game about clicking floating balls. While they have extensive options for how your game looks (colors for balls, floor, roof, walls, etc.), they have like 3 video settings (hey, atleast they added a res scale I guess)

While you can get a quite few more frames by going into the GameUserSettings.ini file in %localappdata%\FPSAimTrainer\Saved\Config\WindowsNoEditor, and changing all sg.xxxQuality values to 0 (with no noticeable difference or game breaking visual bug), or adding launch options for UE4 (-USEALLAVAILABLECORES -sm4 -d3d10 -nomansky -lowmemory -novsync); this really shouldn't be necessary for most, but is. Competitors like AimBeast and Aim Lab offer 2x or even 3x the performance.

I know the Unreal Engine is notorious for subpar framerate, but not to this level. This is just bad code and the main reason I don't recommend or play the game as much as I'd like to. Fix pls
